conclusion: Analyze the motion of the particle in both the electric and magnetic fields.
The particle is launched horizontally with velocity v_0.
The electric field E is directed vertically downward.
The electric force on the particle is F = qE.
The acceleration due to the electric field is a = qE/m.
Horizontal motion equation: x = v_0 t.
Vertical motion equation: y = (1/2) (qE/m) t^2.
Horizontal velocity remains constant: v_x = v_0.
Vertical velocity: v_y = (qE/m) t.
The angle between the velocity vector and the horizontal when entering the magnetic field is 60 degrees.
tan(60 degrees) = v_y/v_x = sqrt(3), therefore v_y = v_0 sqrt(3).
Time to reach point P: t = (v_0 sqrt(3) m)/(qE).
Horizontal distance to point P: x = (v_0^2 sqrt(3) m)/(qE).
The magnetic force provides the centripetal force: qvB = mv^2/R.
The speed v when entering the magnetic field is v = 2v_0.
Radius of circular path: R = (2mv_0)/(qB).
The particle exits between Q and N, implying the radius R must be such that the particle completes a quarter circle or less.
Vertical distance traveled in the electric field: y = (3 v_0^2 m)/(2 qE).
Total distance to point P: d = sqrt((3 v_0^4 m^2)/(q^2 E^2) + (9 v_0^4 m^2)/(4 q^2 E^2)).
Simplified total distance: d = (v_0^2 m sqrt(21))/(2 qE).
The distance from the particle's launch position to point P is (v_0^2 m sqrt(21))/(2 qE).
